question: I'll walk him out. You all right?
answer: Why'd.. .you pull me out?

question: Donley started experiencing the attack for real. If I hadn't gotten you out, the same thing would have happened to you. You may not believe this, Parker, What the hell did you have to shoot the busboy for?
answer: He was a computer program for crissake.

question: You were supposed to act as if everything was real.
answer: Real, my ass. It's an overblown game. Anybody ever catch that fucking psycho?

question: Before you, nobody else had gotten close enough to Sid 6.7 to take a shot at him. Hell, nobody else had even been able to start tracking him before he got to them first. New scar  you making it okay in there?
answer: I'm getting by.

question: ) You've got to know I tried keeping you out of general population. Goddam politicians...
answer: You want to know how I'm doing? Every day, I lose a little bit more of myself. I'm becoming something else, and it scares the hell out of me. But with the six months off I get for being your guinea pig, I've only got to survive another 17 years, 5 months, and 23 days.

question: Don't give up, Parker. Not ever.
answer: You know those cheesy Christmas cards of your family under that tree in your back yard you keep sending me every year?

question: What about them?
answer: Do me a favor  keep sending them.

question: Did you recognize the son-of-a bitch who got away? Think hard -- it'll come to you...
answer: You embarrassed me in front of the highestranking law enforcement official in the country. Do you have any idea how much money you just cost me?

question: The reason you insisted on testing my system with prisoners is because of the increased risks involved with increased realism.
answer: Of the six prison inmates you've tested  all of whom have had at least some military or survival training - only Mr. Barnes is still breathing.

question: I'm still making adjustments...
answer: You've had a yearandahalf to make all the adjustments you want, Lindenmeyer. ) Elizabeth Deane does not give second chances. Neither do I. You're fired.

question: I'M WHAT?!
answer: You are to turn over the Sid 6.7 program, and all its documentation, for immediate destruction. Is that understood?

question: I understand... I understand perfectly.
answer: How does he know who I am?

question: He hears...everything.
answer: As a matter of fact, I do. This is Wallace...

question: I still don't know why they wasted this fancy, new technology on you. Every time I fix you up, you only go and mess it up again. Tell me how this feels...
answer: OW!

question: I'll dial it down a little. That about right?
answer: It'll never feel right.

question: At least they work. Would you rather have no hands at all?
answer: Sometimes.

question: Congratulations, Reilly... To the first LETAC engineer to go into production on prototypes.
answer: As long as you keep overpaying me, I'll be the first to go into production on three, and four, as well.

question: As long as they keep overpaying me, I'll keep overpaying you. ) Just make goddam sure you can have 10 of them ready for deployment around the city by next month.
answer: Mr. Wallace, I could have 10 of them ready by tomorrow.

question: Do they have to look so...robotic?
answer: At this stage, you either get form or function. You said she wanted function. I gave you function. What are you complaining about?

question: I would like the following three things in this order
answer: You actually listen to all those tapes?

question: No, I just like the effect a tape recorder has on you. How you feeling today?
answer: A little less than yesterday.

question: In other words, par for the course. How do you feel about the simulation you participated in yesterday?
answer: John died.

question: I know. I was there. I saw the whole thing. If I was your therapist, I would have advised you against putting yourself back into that kind of situation.
answer: You're not my therapist. You're hear to study me. Face it  I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.

question: That's not true, Parker.
answer: If I had died yesterday, you'd have already dissected my brain and analyzed it to see if I carry any genetic predisposition toward violence.

question: What was going through your mind when you killed the busboy?
answer: Not much. He was just a computer program. Nothing more.

question: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did. You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...
answer: Go to hell.

question: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it? But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.
answer: Enough!

question: GET OUT! I need to know what snapped in you. What made you capable of it. You have to make me understand.
answer: I don't have to do anything except survive. And it's taking everything I've got just to do that.

question: Oh, believe me, it is. It is... HEY!!!
answer: Show's over unless I get to see what you've been working on after hours.

question: I haven't been working on anything.
answer: Do I get to see it or not?

question: Bastard... Sheila, don't go anywhere. I'll be right back.
answer: All my work is my finest. Get that fucking thing away from me!

question: You're...such a wimp. Watching your VR people Auto Reset gave me the idea.
answer: It's nanotechnology, isn't it? Machines the size of molecules...

question: Coordinated by polymer neural net.
answer: It feels so.. .real.

question: It's better than real. It's synthetic flesh. Synthetic blood. Synthetic organs... It's a physiological machine.
answer: This is supposed to be years away.

question: As far as the public is concerned, it is. The reason you got fired, and I got my second demo into production, is I'm a lot smarter than you. I never give my best stuff away.
answer: How do you kill it?

question: Separate the character module from the neural net... ... and you get nanodeath. Don't worry, I've got a bunch of other ones.
answer: Amazing. I hate to say it, but it is.

question: I know. I'm ready to incubate something a little more advanced than a coldblooded reptile. If you want to experience the future, meet me in my office in 15 minutes. And bring the Sheila 3.2 character module with you...
answer: I think I understand what you have in mind...

question: opening his office door for Lindenmeyer fifteen minutes later. Reilly immediately double bolts the door behind him and leads Lindenmeyer through piles of electronic circuitry. As well as a large aquarium full of nanopythons.
answer: You need a maid.

question: What I need is a nymphomaniac. Where's the Sheila 3.2 module? It feeds on what is basically amniotic fluid. In eight hours, we are going to have ourselves one hell of a play toy. Baby, what I'm gonna do to you... Who the hell is this?!
answer: SID  NO!!!

question: Catch him and your record's clean.
answer: What happens if I can't catch him?

question: If Sid 6.7 hasn't killed you, we throw you back in here and you serve out the rest of your sentence.
answer: How do you know I won't run?

question: But only you will know he's not human.
answer: Ms. Deane, you wanted to see me?

question: We have an emergency situation which requires somebody with expertise in criminal psychology. Under the authority vested in me by the President, I'm giving you temporary reassignment.
answer: What's the assignment?

question: You're going to put your theories to practice. I'm sending you into the field.
answer: Quite an improvement. Hair well above the collar standard, L. A. P. D. regulation. What exactly am I going to be doing in the field? This is Parker Barnes six years ago. The most decorated cop in the history of L. A. P. D. Special Investigations Division...

question: That's also where Mr. Barnes lost his arms to Mathew Grimes' booby trap. What's your point, Dr. Carter?
answer: Letting a lunatic like Parker Barnes loose in the free world is like lighting a fuse. At some point, he will go off -- you saw what happened in the simulator. The risk to the public is unacceptably dangerous.

question: Not if you're with him every step of the way.
answer: The man played judge, jury, and executioner with eight people's lives. He lost control and is capable of doing it again.

question: She's going to help you understand what makes Sid 6.7 tick.
answer: What she's going to do is get in my way.

question: This is the personnel file on the programmer, Lindenmeyer. There might be something in it you can use.
answer: She wasn't part of the deal, Cox.

question: Fine  you want to stay here? Officers in Toluca Lake just found an affluent couple...completely gutted. So were the first two cops to arrive on scene.
answer: Their weapons missing?

question: Sid 6.7 is now armed.
answer: Where's my gun?

question: You remember how to get to Toluca Lake? What are you doing?!
answer: Every day for the last five years, I told myself someday I would be out here again. No more bars. No more guards. No more fights just to stay alive. Every day for the last five years, I told myself that lie.

question: It wasn't a lie.
answer: Every time I said it, it was. I never really thought I was going to make it.

question: You all right?
answer: Fine. Never felt better in my life. See, I'm a good liar.

question: You ready for this?
answer: Don't worry. If I can't handle it, I'll just kill everybody.

question: He was reenacting Charles Manson's LaBianca murders.
answer: Manson didn't kill the first cops to arrive on the scene.

question: Whoever did this wanted to do Charlie one better  to improve upon what was already done.
answer: Charlie? You say that like you're close, personal friends.

question: I've spent over 50 hours interviewing him. Charlie killed Leno and Rosemary LaBianca because of the ugly way the members of his family had butchered Sharon Tate. After seeing the blood bath on television, he wanted to show them how it should be done. The question is, what does Charlie have to do with Sid 6.7?
answer: I know who would know.

question: You drive well for somebody who hasn't done it in five years.
answer: Learn anything from Lindenmeyer's file?

question: He had a twin brother who was a musical child prodigy who died in an electrical accident at age eight. Lindenmeyer went into an emotional shell until was 17. All he did day and night was play the violin.
answer: What happened when he was 17?

question: Every music school in the country rejected him and he turned to computers. Stay here. Any sign of Lindenmeyer? Mind if we take a look inside? Do what you've got to do. So will I... You've got a problem with me carrying a gun?
answer: Do me one favor  if you shoot at anything, make sure I'm nowhere near it. Bang... What are you doing?

question: Checking my pulse. It's elevated. You enjoy frightening me, don't you?
answer: You've studied me, now I'm studying you. Seems only fair, don't you think?

question: This Lindenmeyer's a real piece of work.
answer: Maybe after they catch him, you should write a book about him... I'm surprised you didn't write one about me.

question: I'm still working on it. Remember a few years ago when music schools were using a computerized teaching tool that accidently started frying kids' brains?
answer: I've been in prison, remember?

question: The government must have figured there was no better person to create a psycho than a psycho.
answer: Just like they figured there was no better person to catch one...

question: I am the demon from the bottomless pit...
answer: ... here on earth to create havoc and terror. I am War, I am death. I am destruction. David Berkowitz,

question: I am impressed.
answer: For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak with most miraculous organ.

question: Who said that?
answer: Hamlet. What's David Berkowitz got to do with Sid 6.7?

question: He's part of the mix. Sid 6.7 is a composite. Lindenmeyer put increasingly complex combinations of criminal psychological profiles together to develop the ultimate villain.
answer: Creating a whole far more dangerous than the sum of its parts.

question: But rather than selecting pieces from each individual, he simply let the stronger traits of each individual cannibalize the weaker ones. It's a good bet a couple of the dominant personalities teamed up to overpower the others. The question is, which one of the dominants then finally managed to take control? ) He'll let us see the ingredients that went in, but not how the soup turned out after stirring.
answer: This is getting you pumped up, isn't it? This is like the World Series to you.

question: As a matter of fact, it is.
answer: Remember the bowling ball bag Sid carried with him in virtual reality?

question: Dahmer carried the head of one of his victims in a bowling bag for over a week. Kept it in his locker while he was at work in a candy factory. We need to get a look at Sid 6.7's final profile.
answer: What we need to do is stop playing with computers and go catch the sonof-a-bitch before he kills anybody else.

question: What are they doing in Los Feliz?
answer: Madison lives two blocks from their present location.

question: Why would they be going there?
answer: I don't know.

question: Not this one, but the next one. The one with the bicycle out front...
answer: I'll wait out here.

question: Give me your wrist.
answer: Give me a goddam break. I'm not going to go anywhere alone.

question: And I'm going to make sure of it. Give me your wrist. Grimes, you better not be the dominant.
answer: Told you I wasn't going to go anywhere.

question: How did you get your hand out?
answer: Sometimes, I like being part machine. Why didn't you tell me you had a daughter?

question: I prefer keeping my professional life separate from my personal life.
answer: She's beautiful, you know?

question: Thank-you. Her name is Karin.
answer: Want to tell me the real reason we stopped at your house?

question: I told you, it was on the way and I wanted to change clothes.
answer: You should practice lying more often. You're awful at it. Where to?

question: Sid 6.7 is no longer bound by his programming.
answer: What does that mean?

question: Now that he's in the real world, there are no longer limitations on his behavior like there were in virtual reality. Sid is going to evolve.
answer: Sounds to me like a welleducated way of saying you have no idea what to do next.

question: What I do know is that whatever he's becoming, Sid 6.7 is going to be even worse than he was before.
answer: Then all we can do is stay mobile and alert. He's got to make a move sometime, and we've got to be ready when he does. Welcome to police work. You better like coffee.

question: buying two coffees from a downtown street vendor. She returns to the squad car, which is barely moving. Traffic is at a near standstill because of an accident.
answer: I forgot what real coffee tastes like...

question: You know, considering you've only been out of prison for seven hours, you're readapting quite well. Wait, I didn't mean that the way it sounded. I meant...
answer: Don't worry about it, all right?

question: Dammit, I hate sounding so clinical all the time. All I meant to say was I thought you were doing well, but then I...
answer: Relax. I know what you meant.

question: I ruin so many moments by analyzing them when I should just be living them.
answer: Then why don't you start practicing and keep your mouth shut for a while?

question: That's only a couple blocks from here.
answer: I'll meet you there.

question: Don't get out of the car.
answer: Stop me.

question: Parker! PARKER! Shit! What the hell's going on?!
answer: This is my area of expertise.

question: What did you do to those people?
answer: Nothing.

question: Being on the street's a little different than sitting in an office all day, isn't it?
answer: Enjoying yourself?

question: You know I am.
answer: This isn't a game, Parker!

question: Tell him.
answer: That who I think it is?

question: Call me whatever you want, asshole. The only thing I want to hear is your silence. You and me have nothing in common.
answer: You have nothing in common.

question: ... illegal search of Lindenmeyer' s duplex. Eleven civilian vehicles damaged or destroyed. Twentyfour citizen complaints. And the calls are just starting to come in... I forgot what it's like to have you on the streets.
answer: Any sign of Lindenmeyer?

question: None. He could be hiding, he could be helping Sid, or could be in little pieces on Santa Monica beach. Any idea what Sid's going to do next?
answer: Until we know what new influences are affecting him, we can't be sure.

question: Yes. But then I tripped over an erasure mine.
answer: In English, please.

question: I accidently triggered a protection mechanism which erased the entire program. It was very wellhidden. There was no way to see it until it was too late.
answer: It's not your fault. We appreciate you trying.

question: SLOW DOWN!
answer: charges after him. A heatseeking missile locked on target.

question: Parker.. .Parker!
answer: Real effective security...

question: You could have just flashed him your badge, you know?
answer: Authority still makes me nervous.

question: Which way?
answer: Both. hesitates at the escalator leading to the south-bound side of the tracks. Further down the tunnel is the escalator to the northbound trains. Parker chooses the escalator closest to him.

question: SHIT!
answer: peeking out from behind the pillar on the south-bound platform. moves toward the edge of the platform, aiming his gun across the tracks. Those around him quickly back away. Everybody get down! GET DOWN!!! doesn't hesitate. He lines up his shot and pulls the trigger. fires again. Repeatedly. Moving closer and closer to the edge of the platform, trying to get a better angle while he still has a shot.

question: leaps off the descending escalator on the southbound side and rushes to Parker. What were you shooting at?
answer: Sid's getting away.

question: Parker - stop! STOP! Don't make me shoot you
answer: If you're gonna do it, better do it now.

question: lines up her shot. Hands shaking. With both fear and determination. Her finger presses down on the trigger...but she can't do it. Dammit! Let me help you...
answer: I lost him...

question: Call 9-1-1. Wait for me above ground. Do you have any idea the trauma you put that kid through?!
answer: That's Grimes... The man who killed my wife...who killed my daughter...who ruined my life used to taunt me with that line... Grimes is back! He's back! He's come back!!!

question: No! Grimes isn't back. He's only one part of Sid. Sid 6.7 is a hell of a lot worse than Grimes ever was. Get a hold of yourself!
answer: But he's in there. And you knew it, didn't you? Didn't you?! God, you fucking know-it-all! You've known all along and didn't tell me! Why?! Were you afraid I'd lose it?! Go over the edge?! Huh?! Is that what you were afraid of?! WHY DIDN'T YOU TELL ME??!!!

question: Parker... I should have told him.
answer: Don't blame yourself. In your shoes, I don't think I would have told Parker, either. So do you think Grimes has become the dominant personality?

question: I'm not sure. My guess is that's what Sid wants us to think.
answer: You think he's smart?

question: Oh, shit! speeding recklessly through city streets in her car. She doesn't stop for red lights. Not for grid-lock. Not for nothing. There is no way Parker killed those guards. No way.
answer: I think we both know who did. What's so urgent?

question: I need your help--
answer: Why didn't anybody tell me?!

question: I don't set policy. You have the key?
answer: This is a police department. I'll be damned if this is going to go on without my knowledge. Give me 30 seconds, then flip every switch you can reach.

question: Then I guess we're even.
answer: How did you find out about the toxin?

question: Sid 6.7 told me after he killed the two guards. He suggested I kill you rather than him.
answer: You're not capable of it.

question: I pose an unacceptable danger to the public, remember?
answer: I was wrong. And I was wrong not to tell you Grimes was part of Sid. I should have told you. I won't make the same mistake again.

question: The rally's a little obvious as a target, don't you think?
answer: I told you before, Grimes liked to be obvious.

question: Sid 6.7 isn't Grimes.
answer: Part of him is. puts down his binoculars. Madison does not. See something?

question: Can I ask you something?
answer: You mean there's something you haven't asked me?

question: You've already fulfilled the terms of your pardon. You stopped Sid 6.7 and you've got his module. You're free to go  right now. Why are you going to do this?
answer: You don't know?

question: That's why I'm asking.
answer: Because this painintheass criminal psychology expert has helped me understand what I'm capable of. And what I'm not. And better than anyone else, I am capable of stopping Sid 6.7. What C-4...was Cox talking about? Where did you plant the C-4?! You can't die until you tell me where the C-4 is. Where is it?!

question: I told you this would work.. By setting back the clocks, he has absolutely no idea he's in virtual reality. He still thinks he's in the real world.
answer: What's wrong with Parker?

question: How should I know?
answer: Show me his physical sensory level.

question: I wonder how that...
answer: Turn it down!

question: What's wrong?
answer: He's developing a hemisphere imbalance.

question: Talk so I can understand.
answer: If I don't adjust the level of neural information each side of his brain is receiving, he won't be able to walk when I take him out of

question: Then fix it.
answer: I need you to hold this. It can't get any dirt on it. All you have to do is hold the needle at the base. Just make sure not to jab yourself with the point... Hand me the connector nice and... God, some people are stupid.

question: finally losing his grip on the roof of the Hollywood Tower in virtual reality. He plummets with accelerating speed.
answer: You okay?

question: ...I think so...You?
answer: More or less.

question: Lindenmeyer?
answer: My guess is dead.

question: Sid?
answer: I don't know. Let's get out of here.

question: Elizabeth Deane, please. Tell her it's Parker Barnes...
answer: Barnes, where the hell have you been?!

question: Trying to find out where the bomb is. Where the hell have you been?
answer: What did you find out?

question: Call off the manhunt looking for me. I didn't kill the transport guards.
answer: It's already been called off. Witnesses confirmed you weren't the shooter. Did you find out where the bomb is?

question: No, but I've confirmed the reelection rally is the target. How much C-4 is missing?
answer: Enough to level an entire city block.

question: If I were you, I'd get every demolition team in the city searching in and around the Biltmore Hotel.
answer: Demolition teams have searched everywhere in and around the hotel. I don't know where...

question: Sid is smart enough to know you'd check everywhere in the immediate area. Whatever the device is, he's probably got it timed to move into position just before it detonates. Have the demo teams check every subway tunnel, water pipe, gas pipe, and sewer pipe that goes under, over, or into the arena.
answer: You know how much man power you're talking about?

question: You're the highest law enforcement official in the country. Use the fucking army if you need to.
answer: This better not be a wild goose chase.

question: Or what, you'll authorize my death a second time today?
answer: Don't forget, convict, if this psycho isn't stopped, you go right back to rotting in a prison cell.
